issue.title: Significant sensor data timestamp accuracy regression from Gazebo2 to Gazebo4

content.raw:
I just tried it but it did not make a difference. These are images of gazebo output running the flyingKinect Plugin with some traces, that you can see [here](https://github.com/RoboticsURJC/JdeRobot/tree/master/src/stable/drivers/gazeboserver/plugins/flyingKinect) (It is by the way part from a project from my university called [JdeRobot](http://jderobot.org/Main_Page), a software development suite for robotics and computer vision applications). The camera sensor is running at 10 Hz and the real time update rate at 10 Hz too (I also have tried to run it way faster and it does not matter, I still get the position before the image sometimes). The first image is the output before changing that line and the second one the output after the change. Both images shows a small single change in the position of the camera:

![GazeboSimTimes before change.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1441854463-GazeboSimTimes_before_change.png)

![GazeboSimTimes after change.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/500776109-GazeboSimTimes_after_change.png)

As it can be seen in the green selections, it changes the LastMeasurementTime as expected, because in the second image is always equal to LastUpdateTime. But, as it can be seen in the red selections, sometimes, the position is updated sooner than the image. It is specifically in those moments when I get erroneous measurements.
content.html:
I just tried it but it did not make a difference. These are images of gazebo output running the flyingKinect Plugin with some traces, that you can see here (It is by the way part from a project from my university called JdeRobot, a software development suite for robotics and computer vision applications). The camera sensor is running at 10 Hz and the real time update rate at 10 Hz too (I also have tried to run it way faster and it does not matter, I still get the position before the image sometimes). The first image is the output before changing that line and the second one the output after the change. Both images shows a small single change in the position of the camera:

As it can be seen in the green selections, it changes the LastMeasurementTime as expected, because in the second image is always equal to LastUpdateTime. But, as it can be seen in the red selections, sometimes, the position is updated sooner than the image. It is specifically in those moments when I get erroneous measurements.
